body:
And with added -vv

```
MyUserName@MyServer:~/files/acd-MyUserName@gmail.com/local/TV$ ~/bin/rclone moveto  -vv "acd-MyUserName-gmail-com-crypt:TV/Avatar" "acd-MyUserName-gmail-com-crypt:TV/Avatar The Last Airbender"
2017/04/07 07:52:07 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.36-20-g2fd86c9β" starting with parameters ["/home7/MyUserName/bin/rclone" "moveto" "-vv" "acd-MyUserName-gmail-com-crypt:TV/Avatar" "acd-MyUserName-gmail-com-crypt:TV/Avatar The Last Airbender"]
2017/04/07 07:52:12 INFO  : Encrypted amazon drive root 'crypt/170.oq/0.Bwbubs Uif Mbtu Bjscfoefs': Modify window not supported
2017/04/07 07:52:12 DEBUG : Encrypted amazon drive root 'crypt/170.oq/0.Bwbubs Uif Mbtu Bjscfoefs': Using server side directory move

2017/04/07 07:52:13 INFO  :
Transferred:      0 Bytes (0 Bytes/s)

MyUserName@MyServer:~/files/acd-MyUserName@gmail.com/local/TV$

```

Hello.

I think I have a similar bug. rclone v1.36-20-g2fd86c9β and Amazon Cloud Drive too.

So, I was synching some music stuff, and notice one file showed up the same way on the crypted, and encrypted "side". With the encrypted name. Here some screenshots : 
![rclonebug1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22431162/24837609/39918102-1d38-11e7-8a76-4293db45e53d.jpg)

![rclonebug2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22431162/24837610/3fe1aeba-1d38-11e7-9dea-e667f227bf32.jpg)


The jobs log are : 
`2017/04/09 15:14:07 INFO  : Encrypted amazon drive root '114.fGBpxntr nHGEr/16.BE6/104.Kls Krs/24.XQJLPMEBOB/233.HAtvzwolyl - ZlClu'z ayhClsz (YlAhps) (6447) [MUa]': Modify window not supported
2017/04/09 15:14:07 INFO  : Encrypted amazon drive root '114.fGBpxntr nHGEr/16.BE6/104.Kls Krs/24.XQJLPMEBOB/233.HAtvzwolyl - ZlClu'z ayhClsz (YlAhps) (6447) [MUa]': Waiting for checks to finish
2017/04/09 15:14:07 INFO  : Encrypted amazon drive root '114.fGBpxntr nHGEr/16.BE6/104.Kls Krs/24.XQJLPMEBOB/233.HAtvzwolyl - ZlClu'z ayhClsz (YlAhps) (6447) [MUa]': Waiting for transfers to finish
2017/04/09 15:14:08 INFO  :
Transferred:   2.111 MBytes (923.063 kBytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            0
Elapsed time:        2.3s
Transferring:
*                   13-atmosphere-shoes-fnt.wma: 100% done, 0 Bytes/s, ETA: 0s

2017/04/09 15:14:09 INFO  : 13-atmosphere-shoes-fnt.wma: Copied (new)
2017/04/09 15:14:09 INFO  :
Transferred:   2.111 MBytes (707.278 kBytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            1
Elapsed time:          3s`


After it's uploaded, I can't delete or do anything with the file with rclone. I have to delete it with the ACD website... I just uploaded about 5to of data. That the one I notice "by accident", but of 72k files, I guess there is other bug like this...

Of course I tried to delete, reup, etc, same thing.

EDIT : Ok i can confirm other files are impacted. Easy way to find them are to start a sync (with no change on the source). Then in the log, I will see a lot of files being deleted. It's the ones with a screwed name. After the sync is finished, the files uploaded have still a screwed name, and are deleted again (and reup again) if I start another sync. 

BTW sorry for my english, it's not my native language.
@sweharris fancy having a look at this?

Oh!  That's... annoying.

I can replicate:
```
$ rclone copy asdf foo:TV/asdf
$ rclone ls foo:TV
        0 asdf/x1
$ rclone moveto foo:TV/asdf foo:"TV/Avatar The Last Airbender"
$ rclone ls foo:TV                                            
        0 JEjCjA cqn UjBC JrAknwmnA/x1
$ rclone ls Amazon:foo 
       32 170.XZ/0.JEjCjA cqn UjBC JrAknwmnA/169.A5
```

We can see the "0.JEj..." part.  That 0 means that the calculated rotate distance was zero, and the _deobfuscate_ routine takes the zero to mean "no rotation" (which should normally only happen when the string isn't a valid runeString).  

Changing one character - eg "Avatar the Last Airbender" caused a different rotate distance to be calculated which didn't suffer the problem.

I'll take a look today, but it may not be until after work (depending on how busy I get).  I have some guesses...

OK, yes, the problem is what I thought; the filename calculated distance is 0(mod 256).  Approximately 1 in 256 files would be expected to hit this problem.  (Even though the sum is zero, the actual rotation isn't zero because we add the nameKey afterwards to get the real rotation distance).

Now there's some ways I can fix this:
1) Change the calculation  (eg "(dir mod 255 ) + 1").
2) Change what we store in the filename (eg "dir+1" as the prefix)
3) kludge things; if the sum is calculated as 0 then make it 1
4) Change the "invalid string" flag (eg use a "!" instead of a "0" as the first character).

Options 1 and 2 will incompatible with existing obfuscated filenames because the filenames generated won't match.  All existing obfuscated files will need to be uploaded.  Sure, it's a beta version, but it may hurt a number of people.  Option 3 will keep compatibility with approx 99.6% of all files; the existing "0" files will need to be re-uploaded.  Option 4 will break any current "invalid unicode" files but everything else should work correctly.  I expect (but can't prove) this to be a small number.

I think this is a decision for @ncw as to how he would like to see it done... each option will have some impact!

Thx for the explanations . Can you confirm that drsmithy problem and mine is the same ?

Thx again.

@Rootax - if you look at the files on the ACD site (or do an `rclone ls` of the underlying ACD filesystem) do the bad names all begin with `0.` ?  If so, then it's the same problem.

I _think_ it is, based on my test:

```
$ rclone copy 13-atmosphere-shoes-fnt.wma foo:
$ rclone ls Amazon:foo
       32 0.79-jCvxByqnAn-BqxnB-owC.Fvj
```
We can see the name begins with "0".

Ah yes, it always start with 0 indeed.

For the record I'm fine with every solution, even 1 and 2. Like you said, it's a beta, and we know the risks. If re-uploading everything is the way to go for a "cleaner" solution, then I'm all for it.
which beta was this problem introduced in?

It's been in the obfuscate code since that function was introduced; change 6e003934fc1e8fb1fd4b6a549dcda0d964c1a4e4, and which was merged in on March 29th; https://github.com/ncw/rclone/pull/1235

(It wasn't in 1.36; it'll be new in 1.37)

@sweharris 
It will probably be silly but if you add "0." in front of the plaintext : 
`               return "0." + plaintext`

why not check too "0." instead of simply "0"?
`       if num == "0" {`

That way the number of upped files afected will be reduced.

Ok, sorry.
I talked just with the information on the message, i had have to check all the source.
It cannot be so easy :(

Sorry mate.

Thanks for looking at this everyone.

That 1 in 256 files is a bit scary.  Having put ~10T of stuff up into ACD over the last couple of weeks it'd be great if there was some way of programmatically identifying which files/folders have been affected. :)

@drsmithy if you look at the raw filenames from the unencrypted store (eg "rclone ls Amazon:base_dir") then any filename beginning "0." is impacted.  To compare that to a local tree you'd need to do an "rclone ls acd-my-user-encrypted" and then compare the results to a local "find . -type f" (with sorting and filtering; it's a simple script).  Directory misnames (as in your "Airbender" example) are the most annoying, because every file in that directory is good, but the directory name is bad.

Of course only obfuscated files are impacted; if you use "none" or "standard" for filename_encryption then you're not impacted.

For the "obfuscated" case, option 4 from my list of fixes would make these files work again without any change, as long as the original filename was valid unicode (so if the filenames were pure ASCII then you'd be fine).  Any files with broken unicode names would need to be re-uploaded.   I expect that to be the least impactful solution (and is my preferred option), but since all options have impact I'm deferring to @ncw as to what fix he'd like to see.

There are some kludges you can do for immediate relief, but they may not be compatible, going forward.  For example, from the ACD web UI, any "0.randomstuff" entry you see, you could rename to "0.good_name".  Now the current rclone interface will show it as "good_name".  If we pick option 4 as the go-forward solution then you'll later need to rename it to "!.good_name", so this _is_ just a kludge and not recommended...
